author: UOL
title: Arsenal perde do West Ham e desperdiça chance de tirar Liverpool da liderança do Inglês
text: O Arsenal foi derrotado pelo West Ham nesta quinta-feira e, com isso, não conseguiu retomar a liderança do Campeonato Inglês. Pela 19ª rodada, no Emirates Stadium, os visitantes venceram por 2 a 0, com gols de Tomás Sucek e Konstantinos Mavropanos. O meia Lucas Paquetá, que também atua pela Seleção Brasileira, teve que ser substituído ainda no primeiro tempo por conta de dores na panturrilha esquerda. O jogador sentiu durante o aquecimento, mas ainda assim tentou jogar. Depois de 33 minutos em campo, precisou sair. Os Gunners foram ultrapassados pelo Liverpool, que venceu nesta rodada e alcançou 42 pontos. Com 40, o Arsenal terminou a rodada na segunda colocação. Seu próximo desafio será no domingo, às 11h (de Brasília), contra o Fulham, em Craven Cottage. O West Ham subiu para a sexta posição, com 33 pontos, separado por três da zona de classificação para as competições europeias. A equipe volta a campo na terça-feira, para receber o Brighton no Estádio Olímpico de Londres, a partir das 16h30. Os gols do jogo O Arsenal dominou a posse de bola durante todo o primeiro tempo. Os donos da casa focaram seus ataques pelo lado direito, com Saka e Odegaard jogando próximos. Ainda assim, foi o West Ham quem abriu o placar. Aos 13 minutos, a defesa dos Gunners se atrapalhou na tentativa de cortar um cruzamento. O atacante Jarrod Bowen impediu a saída da bola pela linha de fundo e tocou para o meio. Tomás Soucek apareceu no meio da área para completar. O VAR chegou a revisar o lance para investigar uma possível saída da bola no momento da assistência, mas validou o gol. O West Ham ampliou a vantagem pouco depois do início do segundo tempo. Aos 10 minutos, Ward-Prowse cobrou um escanteio na medida para Konstantinos Mavropanos cabecear com firmeza. O zagueiro subiu mais alto que os marcadores e desviou para o canto superior direito, a bola chegou a tocar no travessão antes de entrar. Pouco antes do apito final, os visitantes marcaram mais uma vez. Emerson foi derrubado dentro da área por Declan Rice e um pênalti foi marcado. Benrahma cobrou no canto direito e o goleiro David Raya caiu para defender. Logo na sequência, o árbitro assinalou o final da partida. João Pedro marca dois, e Brighton vence Tottenham O Brighton encerrou uma sequência de três jogos sem vencer nesta quinta-feira, com um triunfo contra o Tottenham por 4 a 2, no Falmer Stadium. O destaque da partida foi o atacante da Seleção Brasileira, João Pedro, que marcou dois gols de pênalti. Jack Hinshelwood e Pervis Estupinán marcaram completaram o placar para os mandantes, enquanto Alejo Véliz e Ben Davies descontaram para os visitantes. O resultado levou o Brighton para a oitava colocação, agora com 30 pontos. Seu próximo compromisso será contra o West Ham. O Tottenham seguiu no quinto lugar, com 36, e volta a campo para enfrentar o Bournemouth.

author: Reuters
title: Autodesk Forecasts Upbeat Annual Revenue on Steady Design Software Demand
text:
(Reuters) - Autodesk forecast annual revenue and profit above Wall Street estimates on Thursday, boosted by strong demand for its design and engineering software across industries such as construction and manufacturing.
The company also said it would reduce its workforce by about 9%, representing roughly 1,350 employees, and laid out plans to invest more heavily in cloud and artificial intelligence, adding that it would reallocate resources towards those areas.
Companies across sectors such as architecture, engineering, construction and product design are making extensive use of Autodesk's 3D design solutions, with the software maker's artificial intelligence and machine learning capabilities further driving spending on its products.
Autodesk saw a 23% jump in total billings to $2.11 billion in the fourth quarter ended January 31.
The company's international operations have particularly shown strength, while analysts have also noted that the company was outpacing peers in the manufacturing sector, driven by the performance of its 'Fusion' design software.
Shares of the San Francisco, California-based company were up about 2% in extended trading.
Autodesk expects full-year revenue between $6.90 billion and $6.97 billion, largely above analysts' average estimate of $6.90 billion, according to data compiled by LSEG.
It projected an adjusted profit between $9.34 and $9.67 per share for its fiscal year 2026, also above the $9.24 per share estimated by analysts.
The company reported total revenue of $1.64 billion in the fourth quarter, up 12% from last year and above analysts' average estimate of $1.63 billion. It posted an adjusted profit of $2.29 per share, beating estimates of $2.14 per share.
(Reporting by Deborah Sophia in Bengaluru; Editing by Mohammed Safi Shamsi)

author: The Virginian-Pilot and Daily Press Editorial Board
title: Editorial: NASA Langley, Wallops Island ensure Virginia’s central role in space exploration – The Virginian-Pilot
text:
From the stunning images beamed to Earth from the remarkable Webb Space Telescope to further advancement in spaceflight pioneered by public and private entities, 2023 was an exciting year in our exploration of the heavens.
That progress is expected to continue in 2024, highlighted by a manned mission to the moon among other promising efforts. The commonwealth will be a featured player in that effort, and its important that Virginia officials continue to support spaceflight operations and the potential economic boom they represent.
Go outside on a clear winter’s night, away from the shine of city lights, and it’s easy to be thrilled and awestruck by the majesty of the heavens. The inky black of space is filled with the unknown, and it’s little wonder that mankind set off to explore it when it developed the means to do so.
This year, images captured by the Webb telescope, a technological marvel, brought those faraway celestial bodies closer than ever, with each new photo revealing something inspiring and wonderful. Already scientists have collected reams of data that they believe will help them learn more about the universe.
This year also saw NASA achieve a number of important milestones toward the larger goal of returning humans to the moon for the first time since December 1972 and ultimately traveling to Mars.
Astronaut Frank Rubio completed a full year in space aboard the International Space Station, which this month marked 25 years of continuous flight . NASA also successfully used its Deep Space Optical Communications program to transmit data encoded on a laser over 10 million miles.
The Artemis program, which will take humans back to the moon in 2024 and eventually to Mars, depends on astronauts being comfortable living and working for long stretches of time in space, developing reliable communications systems and a host of other practical issues related to sustained spaceflight.
Developing those systems and successfully returning to the moon will demand plenty from everyone connected to the program. And Hampton Roads can be proud of the essential contributions of NASA Langley in Hampton , where workers are tackling issues related to astronaut safety, launch systems and the safe return of the Orion spacecraft.
There will be ample focus on NASA Langley in the coming year and the Artemis mission draws closer, but that’s not our region’s only space-related effort. The Mid-Atlantic Regional Spaceport on Wallops Island continues to grow its profile as it looks ahead to an exciting 2024.
This month, the Commonwealth Transportation Board appropriated $20 million to expand one of three launch pads at the facility to accommodate larger rockets. According to reporting by the Virginia Mercury, the funding follows an announcement by Northram Grumman that it will develop new rockets with Firefly Aerospace, which will allow it to resupply the International Space Station in the coming years.
There’s also the prospect of commercial spaceflight from Wallops Island, which board members discussed at their December meeting. While that may still be a distant opportunity, it is one worth pursuing as more private companies look to open the heavens to (well-heeled) tourism.
All of that benefits the commonwealth’s bottom line. Maj. Gen. Ted Mercer, CEO and executive director of the Virginia Spaceport Authority, told the Mercury that “for every dollar Virginia has invested into the spaceport, the commonwealth receives nearly $3 back in economic return.”
Beyond that bottom line, though, is the fact that so much work on space has additional benefits, such as in science education for area schools and colleges, or the careers that result from our investment in space flight.
The space sector is rapidly expanding and Virginia — with NASA Langley, Wallops Island and a growing roster of private aerospace companies — is poised to seize that opportunity. Humans have always been enthralled by the mystery and majesty of the heavens. It’s thrilling to see the commonwealth play a leading role in the next stage of space exploration and travel.
